comments.html: Great Post. But does MTU limitations factor into consideration? Our SP was previously looking to provide a layer 2 service across the internet and found that cisco in the last year has put some work into beefing up their MPLS over DMVPN solution on IOS-XE. While VXLAN makes more sense in DCs and even on campus networks what about larger networks? If my math is right using a MPLS over DMVPN with IPSEC enabled solution has less overhead than using VXLAN over DMVPN/IPSEC?
comments.name: Alex

comments.html:
I honestly don't want to know anything about a layer-2 service across the Internet. Just the thought makes me shudder...

As for MPLS- or VXLAN-over-DMVPN, I don't think I've seen anyone using VXLAN yet, but I'm sure that's about to change. From the overhead perspective MPLS definitely makes more sense.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
I completely agree with you about the layer 2 service over the internet; just because you can do something doesn't mean you should. But I bet dollar to doughnuts that some SD-WAN vendor is going to offer it and market it as some great achievement. It wouldn't even be that hard for them since some of the vendors already use VXLAN as a transport technology.

I think the reason I have seen Cisco put deployment effort into fleshing out MPLS over DMVPN was since a client of their's, SpaceX, wanted to leverage it for some reason.

comments.html:
People wanted to run MPLS-over-GRE-over-IPSec (and DMVPN is just a special use case) to build their own MPLS/VPN networks on top of public (or Service Provider) IP infrastructure for a long time. The usual reason is VRF scalability (= we don't want to have a different DMVPN tunnel for every VRF).

https://blog.ipspace.net/2011/03/mplsvpn-over-gre-over-ipsec-does-it.html

It’s just that the sane way of running MPLS-over-DMVPN wasn't well supported due to the way IP multicast/broadcast propagation works over DMVPN. I think I covered various scenarios in either DMVPN or Enterprise MPLS webinars.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: I witnessed a design proposal from DC guys where the entire inter-dc mpls-vpn dedicated backbone (i.e. the ethernet connectivity between P routers) was meant to be migrated over to a vxlan-based full-mesh of tunnels between gateways (I'd call them P gateways) whose IP connectivity was provided by the main and already shared by mobile and fixed and business customers MPLS VPN backbone. Basically a vxlan-based overlaid inner backbone. A true folly. Thank god it didn't pass in the end. They laughed at us when we (backbone/transport engineers) proposed CsC as a solution. This use case fits I guess in the vxlan cathegory that Ivan called "separation between edge (customer-facing) and core (transport) networks" but with the customer being your DC guys and the Provider being your backbone guys as these two groups don't always trust each other. Thank god common sense transport still prevails at times.
comments.name: Andrea Di Donato

comments.html: In support of VxLAN, there's also benefits/advantages to be found in its ability to connect multi-vendor environments with multi-layer use cases (just like OSPF, BPG, ...) and it also has potential to be simply used as a standards-based tag-and-tunnel mechanism which has many LAN, WAN, DC-DC use cases potentially.
